item.title: Jan. 6 Panel Votes to Subpoena Trump as It Wraps Up Its Case
item.description: “He must be accountable,” the committee’s chairman said as it presented a sweeping summation of its findings. But the prospect of the former president testifying appeared unlikely.
item.dc:creator: Luke Broadwater and Alan Feuer
item.category: House Select Committee to Investigate the January 6th Attack
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang/The New York Times
item.media:description: The House Jan. 6 committee on Thursday put former President Donald J. Trump at the center of a sprawling effort to maintain his grip on power that began even before Election Day.

item.title: Jan. 6 Panel Vividly Detailed the Attack. Accountability Is Another Matter.
item.description: Over its nine public hearings, the committee has not moved the needle of public opinion of former President Donald J. Trump. But it may have laid the groundwork for criminal prosecution.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker
item.category: House Select Committee to Investigate the January 6th Attack

item.title: New Jan. 6 Video Shows Pelosi and Schumer Scrambling to Secure the Capitol
item.description: Tense video, shot by Speaker Nancy Pelosi’s daughter, underscored how deeply leaders feared for the safety of their colleagues and staff members.
item.dc:creator: Catie Edmondson
item.category: House Select Committee to Investigate the January 6th Attack
item.media:credit: House Select Committee, via Associated Press

item.title: Texts Show Oath Keepers Coordinated With Other Far-Right Groups
item.description: Prosecutors in the seditious conspiracy trial of five members of the militia presented the messages as evidence of an effort to build an “alliance” with other extremist organizations.
item.dc:creator: Alan Feuer and Zach Montague
item.media:credit: Robert Nickelsberg/Getty Images
item.media:description: Kelly Meggs, the leader of the Florida chapter of the Oath Keepers militia, reached out to allies after President Donald J. Trump tweeted a call to action to his supporters.

item.title: Gunman Who Killed 17 in Parkland Is Spared the Death Penalty
item.description: Nikolas Cruz showed little emotion as the judge read the jury’s decisions one by one. His victims’ families, in contrast, were horrified and baffled as they learned that his life had been spared.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Mazzei and Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
item.media:credit: Eva Marie Uzcategui for The New York Times
item.media:description: A memorial garden outside Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School on Thursday.

item.title: Inflation was much hotter than expected, bad news for the Fed.
item.description: Inflation rose quickly in September and a key measure accelerated to the fastest pace since 1982, underlining the persistence of price increases.
item.dc:creator: Jeanna Smialek

item.title: At Least 5 Killed, Including Off-Duty Police Officer, in Raleigh Shooting
item.description: At least two others were wounded, including a police officer, whose injuries were described as “non-life threatening.” The authorities said late Thursday that a suspect was in custody.
item.dc:creator: Emily Cataneo, Vimal Patel and McKenna Oxenden
item.media:credit: Ethan Hyman/The News & Observer, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Dozens of law enforcement vehicles rushed to the scene of what the authorities called an “active shooter” in Raleigh, N.C., on Thursday.

item.title: How Two Teenagers Became the New Faces of Iran’s Protests
item.description: The 16-year-old girls were killed by the Iranian security services in a crackdown on the protests that have rocked the country for the past month.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi

item.title: Death Toll Rises as Russia Bombards Ukraine’s Cities for a Fourth Day
item.description: Prompted by the expanded strikes, European countries made plans to develop joint air defenses and to train Ukrainian soldiers on European Union soil.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff, Valerie Hopkins and Eric Nagourney
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers with a destroyed Russian tank near the village of Pisky-Radkivski in the Donetsk region on Thursday.

item.title: In Midterm TV Ad Wars, Sticker Shock Costs Republicans
item.description: The party is paying far more for TV ads than Democrats on the exact same programs. The reasons are tied to Republicans’ reliance on super PACs.
item.dc:creator: Shane Goldmacher
item.media:credit: John Locher/Associated Press
item.media:description: Senator Catherine Cortez Masto paid far less for a 30-second television commercial during a Las Vegas Raiders game than a Republican super PAC did.

item.title: 2 Police Officers Killed in Connecticut After a Suspicious 911 Call
item.description: A third officer was seriously wounded in the violence in Bristol, officials said, and a suspect also died. The police chief called it an act of “senseless violence.”
item.dc:creator: Michael Gold, Corey Kilgannon and Hurubie Meko
item.media:credit: Joe Buglewicz for The New York Times
item.media:description: Police officers salute as a body is taken from the scene of the violence in Bristol, Conn.

item.title: Hurricane Ian’s Financial Toll Threatens Florida’s Real Estate Market
item.description: The hurricane’s record-breaking cost will make it even harder for many to get insurance, experts say — threatening home sales, mortgages and construction.
item.dc:creator: Christopher Flavelle
item.media:credit: Callaghan O'Hare for The New York Times
item.media:description: Cleanup in the aftermath of Hurricane Ian in Fort Myers Beach, Fla., on Oct. 5.

item.title: With Leaps and Bounds, Parkour Athletes Turn Off the Lights in Paris
item.description: As an energy crisis looms, nimble young activists are using superhero-like moves to switch off wasteful lights that stores leave on all night.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Kevin Ha, 30, left, leader of the On The Spot Parkour collective in Paris, climbs a wall to turn off a shop’s exterior lights on the Avenue des Champs-Élysées, in September.

item.title: Biden’s Tough Tech Trade Restrictions on China
item.description: America abandons its sunny view of globalization.
item.dc:creator: Paul Krugman
item.media:credit: Ashley Gilbertson for The New York Times

item.title: Why That John Fetterman Interview Caused a Furor
item.description: It is our accommodations, often but not exclusively technological in nature, that make it possible for many of us to do our jobs.
item.dc:creator: David M. Perry
item.media:credit: Jeff Swensen for The New York Times

item.title: The L.A. City Council Scandal Shows What Happens When Race Is Everything
item.description: Stop turning public life into a brutal struggle of group against group.
item.dc:creator: David Brooks
item.media:credit: Mario Tama/Getty Images

item.title: The Jan. 6 Committee Has Been Almost Wholly Ineffective
item.description: It has set itself up as the defender of America’s democracy. It’s the wrong venue for such a mission.
item.dc:creator: Christopher Caldwell
item.category: House Select Committee to Investigate the January 6th Attack
item.media:credit: Jordan Gale for The New York Times

item.title: It Shouldn’t Matter So Much Whether Elon Musk Buys Twitter
item.description: Mr. Musk’s plan to buy Twitter underscores the need for federal regulation of social media sites.
item.dc:creator: Binyamin Appelbaum
item.media:credit: Muhammed Selim Korkutata/Anadolu Agency, via Getty Images

item.title: Elon Musk Has Some Bad Ideas for Mass Transit. We Have Solutions.
item.description: Innovation is important, but Elon Musk’s impractical transit inventions do nothing to help solve today’s problems.
item.dc:creator: Adam Kovacs and Adam Westbrook

item.title: What Exactly Is Ben Sasse the Right Guy For?
item.description: With the junior senator from Nebraska set to become the president of the University of Florida, it’s a good moment to plow into his most recent book.
item.dc:creator: Carlos Lozada
item.category: Them: Why We Hate Each Other -- and How to Heal (Book)
item.media:credit: Drew Angerer/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: The junior senator from Nebraska is nothing if not thoughtful. Right?

item.title: It’s Time to Accept That North Korea Has Nuclear Weapons
item.description: The threat of a Korean conflict is rising and the U.S. has few other cards to play.
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey Lewis
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.media:credit: Illustration by Rebecca Chew/The New York Times; images by Nosyrevy and Komarov Vitaly, via Getty Images

item.title: Your Thursday Evening Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Cullen
item.media:credit: Amanda Andrade-Rhoades for The New York Times
item.media:description: The house committee investigating the January 6 insurrection on Capitol Hill listened to evidence.

item.title: Is America Headed for Another Civil War?
item.description: Jamelle Bouie and Tim Alberta on whether America’s polarization is at a tipping point.
item.dc:creator: ‘The Argument’

item.title: How to Spend a Day in Red Hook
item.description: October can feel like the last hurrah for outdoor life. Make the most of it by eating along the Brooklyn waterfront.
item.dc:creator: Becky Hughes
item.media:credit: Emon Hassan for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Valentino special, with fried eggplant, provolone and peppers, at Defonte’s Sandwich Shop.

item.title: Do You Have Questions About the Social Security COLA? We Want to Hear From You
item.description: Reporters and editors working on our coverage of Social Security will find the answers.
item.media:credit: Lisa Haney

item.title: The Sandy Hook Families’ Looming Battle for Alex Jones’s Millions
item.description: The Infowars fabulist’s empire is only worth a fraction of the $1 billion he has been ordered to pay the families, and he won’t surrender it easily.
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth Williamson and Emily Steel
item.media:credit: Kirsten Luce for The New York Times
item.media:description: Alex Jones was ordered to pay nearly $1 billion in damages to families of Sandy Hook victims.

item.title: Loss of Steele Dossier Source Damaged National Security, F.B.I. Agent Testifies
item.description: The agent denounced the exposure by the Trump Justice Department of Igor Danchenko, who was an F.B.I. informant but is now on trial on charges of lying to investigators.
item.dc:creator: Adam Goldman
item.media:credit: Drew Angerer/Getty Images
item.media:description: Igor Danchenko faces five counts of making false statements to the F.B.I. in the special counsel investigation led by John H. Durham.

item.title: As Immigration Issue Looms, Biden Officials Turn Eye to Latin America
item.description: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken, just back from South America, met again with his Mexican counterpart.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley
item.category: United States Agency for International Development
item.media:credit: Alex Brandon/Associated Press
item.media:description: Marcelo Ebrard, Mexico’s foreign minister, met with U.S. Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken for the second time in just over a month.

item.title: Madison Square Garden Barred Lawyers Representing Clients Suing
item.description: A lawyer who has had Knicks season tickets since the 1970s represents clients who are suing Madison Square Garden. So it barred all 60 of his firm’s lawyers from every game, concert and other event at its venues.
item.dc:creator: Kris Rhim
item.media:credit: Desiree Rios/The New York Times
item.media:description: Larry Hutcher, managing partner at Davidoff Hutcher & Citron LLP, at his Manhattan office on Wednesday.

item.title: Ankle Exercises to Help Strengthen and Prevent Injury
item.description: Ankle instability is often the result of nerve and ligament damage. These exercises can help get you back on, and stay on, your feet.

item.media:credit: Izaiah Johnson for The New York Times

item.title: How to Motivate Yourself to Exercise
item.description: Bundle your incentives. Be flexible. Get some support. Here’s how to get — and stay — motivated.

item.title: Is Barefoot Weight Lifting Safe?
item.description: This strength training practice can fortify your feet, but experts warn that it’s not without risk.

item.title: Is It Possible to Exercise Too Much?
item.description: And if so, how can I tell if I’m overdoing it?

item.title: Ignored in Life, Bernice Bing Is Discovered as Museums Rewrite History
item.description: Scholars and curators are beginning to focus on long-overlooked Asian American artists, acknowledging their importance in the narrative of American art.
item.dc:creator: Carol Pogash
item.category: Cantor, Iris & B Gerald, Center for Visual Arts
item.media:credit: via Estate of Bernice Bing
item.media:description: Overlooked no more: Bernice Bing, who has come to be known for her trailblazing Northern California abstractions, at her studio circa 1970.

item.title: How to Solve Hard Crosswords
item.description: Friday, Saturday and Sunday bring some of the hardest puzzles of the week.
